angles in 1259 meanwhile the Japanese

to bring Japan under his control would

such symbolism mattered for securing and

China in 1266 kou ply sent his first

overt threats of destruction it still
referred to Kublai as master of the
universe and the implication was hardly
hidden in the letters conclusion let us
engage in cordial relations who desires
the resort to arms
while Kublai's letter was addressed to
the emperor since the late 12th century
the Emperor had been a figurehead for
the Shogun and after the death of the
first Shogun real power was held by his
regent the shicken a position controlled
by the Hojo clan coupe lies envoys in
1266 were ignored a brusque reception
the Kahn did not take lightly with
similar responses to envoys in the
following years the silence increasingly
looks like insolence and affront the
most powerful sovereign on earth could
not ignore

Kublai's preparations for this
unprecedented Seabourn mongol invasion
began in 1268 as the Mongols had little
experience in naval warfare
aside from operations on the rivers of
China they relied on the expertise of
Korean sailors and their vessels in
addition the Koreans also supplied the
provisions for the invasion a burden
which led to a short-lived revolt this
uprising gave word to the Japanese of
Mongol preparations and the new shicken
Hojo taka munei began his own
preparations warriors were sent to
Kyushu the most likely site for landings
the fall of the key song stronghold that
shang yang in 1273 freed men and
resources to be sent elsewhere Japan too
could finally receive its retribution
for resisting Kublai's demands

exact numbers for the Mongol forces are
disputed with estimates giving 15,000
Mongol northern Chinese kitten and
Jurchen soldiers six to eight thousand
Korean soldiers and another seven
thousand Korean sailors
spread among some 300 warships and four
to five hundred to smaller vessels a
large contingent but not enough to
occupy a country while Kublai's forces
had never undertaken an overseas
operation before the last 60 years has
provided few folks who could match the
Mongols in battle if the mighty empires
of the Jin and the song bent to the
Mongols how could the small nation of
Japan dare stand before him to cook ly
anything other than a swift victory was
impossible the fleet departed from Korea
in autumn 1274 falling first upon the
small islands of Tsushima and iki these
sparsely defended settlements offered
little resistance to experienced Mongol
warriors for in their isolation from the
mainland
the samurai had developed their own
brand of warfare reliant on individual
jewel rather than the complex formations
of the Mongols
the Mongols left Tsushima and iki with
prisoners nailed to the Prowse of their
ships arriving in Kyushu Cecotto Bay in
November their landing was not unopposed
an old seawall ran along much of the bay
and behind it were stationed to the
Warriors of Hojo took a moon a numbers
for the Japanese force are disputed with
some figures as low as 3,600 and it is
clear that the defenders were
outnumbered with no experience in
fighting foreign forces and lacking the
tactical and strategic ability of the
Mongols with the landing of the yuan
Armada the first battle in Hakata Bay
had begun the samurai were like the
Mongols skilled archers both on foot and
on horseback wielding their signature
asymmetrical you mean the Japanese
opened combat with whistling arrows
designed to unnerve and intimidate their
foes Japanese sources described the
Mongols as laughing at the arrows then
driving the horses of the samurai mad
with fear at the sounds of the war drums
and gongs used to direct Mongol forces
in battle unused to such noise the
Japanese horses panicked before they
even met the enemy
defending their homes and skilled
warriors nonetheless the Japanese
fiercely fought along the seawall the
Mongols fighting uphill from the beaches
were unable to bring their fearsome
cavalry to bear but as shown from
archaeological and pictorial evidence
the Mongols used bombs against the
Japanese in a few places the Mongols
broke through burning down the nearby
town of Hakata the area beyond the
breach proved unfavorable to the Mongols
however the site chosen for their camp
Akasaka proved undefendable and Japanese
archery proved skillful even by Mongol
standards the UN commander Liu Lu Xiang
was struck in the face with an arrow and
had his horse captured by a samurai with
their commander incapacitated unable to
press in land and running low on
munitions
despite inflicting heavy losses on the
Japanese a withdrawal was ordered what
followed next is a matter of some debate
but has become a defining moment of the
campaign Japanese sources for this
invasion describe a reverse wind which
pushed the Mongol flee
beating a few ships one source on the
other hand speak of a great typhoon
which rose up crushing much of the fleet
beneath the waves and forcing evil angel
to retreat the reasons for such an
emphasis are obvious for by blaming a
freak weather accident
the Mongols could maintain their
military reputation
rather than admit that the Japanese had
offered stiffer resistance than
anticipated
neither side saw this first engagement
as decisive and when ku plies envoys in
1275 were executed his return was
ensured in 1279 the Song Dynasty finally
fell to the Mongols completing the
conquest of China begun by Chinggis
Khaan in 1211 now Kublai could raise men
resources and ships from southern China
to use against Japan with Korea
economically devastated by the first
invasion these newly conquered troops
had to take a leading role in Japan
Hojo takumin a did not sit idle
repairing and extending the sea wall
around her cat obey for 20 kilometers as
well as preparing a larger defense
by 1281 Kublai was ready to strike back
gathering perhaps the largest seaborne
invasion before the Normandy landings of
1944 while it is to be expected that
medieval sources inflate numbers it is
clear by any measure that this was a
mammoth undertaking the sources states
that over 100 thousand men were split
between two fleets a northern fleet of
approximately 40,000 Mongols Gershon
northern Chinese and Korean troops
aboard nine hundred ships and another of
around 60,000 men from the newly
conquered territories of southern China
aboard 3500 vessels few of these were
proper ocean-going warships or
transports rather repurposed coastal or
river ships never intended for such
lengthy expeditions immediately the
expedition was off to an inauspicious
start intended to leave in spring to
avoid the typhoon seasons the southern
fleet suffered delays a general fell ill
and food spoiled in the warm weather of
South China the plan had been for the
northern fleet departing again from
Korea to rendezvous on a key with the
southern fleet departing from Toronto
but ultimately the northern fleet set
off alone occupying iki by June 1281 two
weeks later the fleet was off the coast
of Kyushu but found the landing sites
defended by well-prepared Samurai on the
seawall the stout resistance near mana
cotta kept the northern fleet from fully
landing or making progress in land
the southern fleet finally arrived in
July towards the southern end of the
wall and intended to fight their way
north to meet with the first fleet but
this southern fleet composed almost
entirely of Chinese from the recently
conquered Song Dynasty lacks the skill
discipline and experience of the Mongol
troops and had little stake or interest
in risking their lives for foreign
masters in a foreign land the language
barrier between the Mongols Koreans
Chinese and others and tensions between
Mongol and Chinese generals and the
Korean Admiral weakened leadership and
their ability to act from late June to
early August the yuan and Japanese
engaged largely and decisively the yuan
unable to advance against the Japanese
but the Japanese unable to overpower the
great Armada
at night the Japanese took their smaller
nimble craft out among the fleets
climbing aboard and killing men in their
sleep or sending fire ships out to set
ships alight UN losses were mounting
with supplies running low
unable to billet their men on anything
but what they brought with them Knights
aboard kraut rockin ships proved no
respite for Mongol warriors used to
openstep knowing samurai may come
crawling out of the darkness on the 15th
of august 1281 came to kuta grass the
sea off the coast of Kyushu churned as a
typhoon rose unceasingly early the yuan
fleets now caught between the storm and
the coast the sturdier Korean vessels
made for open waters managed to avoid
being crushed against the rocks but be
more makeshift southern fleet was
helpless against the ocean's wrath over
August 15th and 16th perhaps a third of
the Northern Fleet and over half of the
southern were destroyed and the second
Mongol attempt to take Japan was over
those who won soldiers who washed ashore
were swiftly found by the Japanese and
killed while the remainder limped back
into China
Kublai was furious the aura of Mongol
invincibility built up over the century
was not destroyed but was definitely
tarnished and the economic blow was
significant the second invasion was a
massive expenditure of men and resources
much of which now sat at the bottom of
the ocean Korea in particular was
devastated having provided much of the
grain ships materials and young men of
both invasions to cover the costs cupola
had to turn to financial advisors such
as a mad fan okati
and Lee Shi Jung who became infamous for
corruption nepotism and over taxation
assuring an era of financial
mismanagement and increasing
inefficiency
in 1281 a major restraining voice on
curb lie his chief wife chabi died
followed by his heir Jing Kim in 1286
with their deaths curb lie became
increasingly withdrawn from governor's
finding solace in food and drink and
suffering from depression obesity and
gout his military demands grew ever
wilder he ordered a third invasion of
Japan which never materialized launched
invasions of Burma Vietnam and even a
seaborne invasion to Java all of which
ended inconclusively Oran outright
disaster the tropical heat and disease
of southern Asia and dense jungle
rendering mongolian cavalry useless
he faced revolt from Tibet and from his
cousin's Qaeda and denying who
challenged curb lies legitimacy from
Central Asia and Manchuria
all the while his influence over the
Western Carnot's of the Empire grew ever
weaker despite having completed the
conquest of China
Kublai oversaw the fragmentation of the
Mongol Empire Kublai Khan died in
February of 1294 succeeded by his
grandson Tim LJ - the succeeding yuan
Khan's held only nominal authority over
the other Carnot's each going their own
separate paths and collapsing over the
following century it is this collapse of
the Mongol Empire that we will examine
